description: Classical, jazz, pop, opera, and world music are right at home in Koerner Hall. Its high ceiling and first-rate projection and communication technology make it perfect for films, lectures, and educational or corporate conferences. With its layered ribbon of wood forming a floating ceiling canopy, integrating an acoustic reflector, performance lighting, and technical bridges, Koerner Hall provides a dramatic yet intimate ambience between the audience and performers. The spectacular glass lobbies welcome guests to Koerner Hall and offer an extraordinary view of the city.

reviews.title: Opera in Mazzoleni Hall
text: The Royal Conservatory of Music is home to two concert halls. Koerner Hall is deservedly better known, but Mazzoleni Hall should not be overlooked. It's a small space, with around 240 seats, and it has first-rate acoustics. We went there this evening for a student performance of a masque from the Restoration period, Venus and Adonis by John Blow. The students did well, with Elena Howard-Scott giving an outstanding performance. as Venus. It was a most enjoyable hour!

reviews.title: KOERNER HALL...BUT THAT’S NOT ALL
text: If you’re lucky enough to score a couple of tickets to anything at Koerner Hall you’ll be struck with two facts:
Not only the the acoustics fine...but part of concert experience will be spent looking at the architecture.
This is no ordinary concert hall.
The Conservatory of Music was dragged from its turn of the century look and feel by a retro-fit addition that incorporated the old exterior into the new interior to make an altogether satisfying fit.
Come in through the Philosopher’s Walk entrance and have an espresso or tea or anything at all just to sit and look up marvel at what human ingenuity is capable of.
In this incarnation, art is not sacrificed to utility.
Rather both work hand in hand beautifully.
A lovely balance.
And a perfect example of architecture respecting the old and incorporating the new.
Now the conservatory is more than just music.

reviews.title: Excellent acoustics.  Falls down in key areas.
text: Just stepping inside the auditorium is visually impressive.  Once you see the sculpture which snakes it's way up the backdrop and over the ceiling, there's always a WOW reaction.  And the acoustics are excellent.

The main problem is in accessibility.  Many of the concert-goers are more "mature".  The elevator is small and sometimes out of service and it becomes a challenge to climb stairs and traverse long corridors to get to Koerner Hall.

And one thing that most great concert halls have is an organ.  Nothing.  It would be architecturally impossible to find space for the organ loft (poor planning).  However, this would be a great opportunity for a generous benefactor to make a grant to install a SOTA modern electronic organ with sampled voices.  This could easily be rolled on and off the stage and there just MIGHT be room for a small "fake" loft behind the sculpture to house the speaker system.  It's waiting!
